mar easie matter find german mar uenus mercurie iupiter whereof may read hereafter chronologie truth frea albeit saxo giueth hir scant good report loued one hir husband men better himselfe seauen sonnes woden first father wecca whome descended afterwards king kent fethelgeta second came king mercia baldaie third father king west saxon beldagius fourth parent king brenicia northumberland weogodach fift author king deira caser sixt race east angle race nascad originall burgeant king essex king sussex although people yet streine old monument doo expresse procéed certeine day suffered alteration saxon church reteined long time number day feria sabaoth manner iews meane vnstill seruice romane vse abolished custome first receiued thinke pope syluester though saie constantine albeit another sort doo affirme syluester caused sundaie onelie called lord day dealt rest like maner wéekes moneths made called moonemoneth one conteining eight twentie day foure wéekes without anie curiositie reckon time yeare moone iews grecian roman first turk arabian persian doo neither anie parcell thereof said planet part west indie haue neither weeke moneth yéere onlie generall accompt hundred thousand moones wherefore saie write moneth expounded eight twentie day foure wéeks onelie hir vsuall period nine twentie day one thirtie minuts take large moneth common calendertriuethus antartico neuerthelesse plées sutes nothing allowed sith moone maketh hir full reuolution eight twentie day foure week vnto place left sun notwithstanding gone hir returne found verie often signe wherin left plutarch writeth diuers barbarous nation reckoned lesse number moneths whole yeares accompted thrée archadians foure acarnans six aegyptians one whole yeare causeth make large accompt antiquitie originall forsomuch troubled anie disorder shall suffice haue generallie said moneths quantity time word two ancient romane calender old time moneth romane calender reckoned course moone enterances vncerteine also change planet whereby came passe daie change first moneth howsoeuer fell iulius cesar corrected seuerall beginning euerie one onelie remaine fixed also old order diuision part continued still vnaltered moneth yet diuided calends ides none albeit day vse bée small order reteined onelie calender better vnderstanding time historiographer old author doo remember reckoning also goeth sée preposterous order whereby roman rather note many day next change precedent contrariwise perusall shall easilie perceiue day also change moneth moone called calendae time paganisme consecrated iuno sacrifice made goddesse day also ides none would marie likewise morow called dy atri blacke day also diuerse either reason notable ouerthrow mishap befell vnto roman vpon day respect superstitious imagination conceiued euill successe likelie fall vpon called dy aegyptiaci wherby appeareth peeuish estimation day came nation doo note holie festiuall day red letter calender roman principall feast circle moone either red golden letter victory white publike consularie table also added anie good successe happened afterward vpon day alreadie blacke calender would solemnlie enter white letter racing blacke whereby blacke daie turned white wherein little reioised word calendae gréeke neomenia deriued calo call vpon first day euerie moneth priest vsed call people citie countrie togither calabria place called met shew custome manie day said calends none feast celebrated betwéene next change order retrograde moneth halfe expired moone past full reckoned day come vntill next change seuentéene day sixtéene day fourtéene day c gréekes latter decad onelie vse calends verie day therefore change called calendae dedicated iuno thereof also called calendaris first also fast feast day knowne none meanes vnto people denunciation priest said vpon daie till flauius scriba caused written published common calender contrarie meaning senat ease benefit people pretended none commonlie aboue foure six euerie moneth long none lasted long market continue therefore called nonae quasi nundinae also neither holiedaies present except day purification ladie sacrifice offered god one applied businesse kept market reckoning first day calends change fourth sixt daie faire ended thinke called nonae word non quia ijsdem dij non coluntur ouid saith nonarum tutelae deo caret none alwaies ninth daie ides nundina dea honored ninth day ides albeit suppose rather nundina dea goddesse far yoonger name nonae tooke hir name none whereon custome among roman lustrare infantes ac nomina maribus imponere maid child vpon eight howsoeuer sure mart day euerie moneth wherin people bought sold exchanged battered nothing else ides named hethruscan word iduare diuide cesar altered calender diuided moneth commonlie middest afterward added certeine day reto therby make agrée yéere sunne intruded end euerie moneth bicause would alter celebration vsuall feast whereof chiefe holden alwaies vpon day ides came short middest sometime two thrée day therefore alwaies eight merchant leisure packe vp conueie merchandize pay creditor make merie friend ides doo calends follow decreasing order noted moone dooth light past full herein lieth mysterie say manie day next change new moone number expressed dooth betoken 16 calends manie day next coniunction c aboue remembred calends meane touching number euerie moneth find verse insuing ianus augustus denas nouém que december iunius aprilis september ipse nouémber ter senas retinent februs bi octo calendas iulius october mar maius epta decém que english thus december iune august month full nineteene calends haue septemb aprill nouemb iune twise nine doo desire sixteene foule februarie hath well craue october maie iulie hot seuenteene door require like maner doo none ides sex maius nonas october iulius mar quatuor reliqui dabit idus quilibet octo iulie mar october maie six none hight rest foure ides keepe still eight againe touching number day euerie moneth iunius aprilis septém que nouém que tricenos vnumplus reliqui februs tenet octo vicenos si bissextus fuerit superadditur vnus thirtie day hath nouember aprill iune september twentie eight hath februarie alone rest thirtie one leape must ad one yeare counted course sunne although church hath vse moone obseruation certeine mooueable feast yet reducible sunne ciuill dealing chieflie vse herein onelie find scruple beginning thereof vniforme certeine record beare date 25 march calender first ianuarie v christ borne conceiued sundrie officer also haue sundrie entrance charge custome bréedeth great confusion whereas might referred one originall first inuarie doo thinke would certeintie lesse trouble historiographer notary officer account yere old time atheniens began yeare change moone fell néerest enterance sunne crab latines winter solstice going goat iewes ciuill case latter equinoctiall ecclesiasticall first calecute begin yeare somewhere september vpon daie certeine sith first consult wisards pronounce one day thereof happie yeare goeth therewith make entrance osorius dooth remember addeth vpon eleuenth calends september haue solemne play much like idoll game write leaues tree pencill stead paper found among old grecian began yere also september sith seeke herein custome countrie onelie shall enought affirme make account calends first ianuarie middest night lime betwéene last december whereof maie suffice might speake cynike yeare also place ease english reader sometime vse amongst egyptian conteineth 1460 common yeares whose beginning alwaies reckoned rising lesser dog first vse thereof entered selfe yeare wherin olimpiads restored forsomuch nation hath vse intercalation end euerie 1460 yeares added whole yeare intercalation 365 leape yeers period 1460 iulian yéers doo conteine 1461 egyptian account wherby common yeare found lese furthermore wheras intercalation leape yere somewhat much certeine minuts 115 yeares amount vnto whole day one intercalation manie omitted calender would perfect would wish yeare wherein said intercalation trulie found ourpassed might obserued called annus magnus elizabethae perpetuall remembrance noble souereigne princesse reigning amongst v might saie somewhat also prime hir alteration risen higher fiue day common calender placed iulius caesar seauen thousand yeares writer would grow error whole world last long forsomuch calender reduced againe daie euerie change shall suffice saie therof pope also hath made generall correction calender wherein hath reduced haue beene councell nice howbeit hath abolished vse golden number hath continued epact applieng vnto generall vse dooth serue turnes whose reformation also yer time béene admitted england procéeded whose ordinance haue faithfullie sworne set hand certes next omission performed prince would agrée thereto leape yeare shall yeare grace 1668 shall please god world may last long may calender also stand without anie alteration dooth alreadie also appeareth defect calender may supplied creation wherein first equinoctiall seene higher toward beginning march caesar calender extant dooth yéeld vnto seauen day caesar time true equinoctiall pointed happen stadius also noteth either vpon sixtéenth seauentéenth march albeit manifest apperance thereof found vntill fiue twentith moneth dial eiesight heretofore said sufficientlie faires chapter fair market performe promise made set downe manie faires haue found mine owne obseruation helpe others behalfe certes impossible come sith almost towne england hath one mart holden yearelie although must need confesse scarse comparable lowse faire little else bought sold good drinke pie pedlerie trash wherefore losse diuerse abolished neither doo see wherevnto number paltrie fair tendeth much corruption youth businesse set apart must néeds repaire vnto whereby often spend onelie weeke day also lord sabbaoth great vanitie riot hath béene iniquitie ancient time god grant therefore ignorance abolished insight thing growne mind magistrate old error may considered farre reformed thereby neither god may dishonored common wealth countrie anie thing diminished meane time take table insuing stead calender greatest sith cannot least wise care come name lesse whose knowledge cannot profitable farre oft preiudiciall dwell neere hand place holden kept thorowfaires chap 16 townes call thorowfaires haue great sumpthous innes builded receiuing trauellers stranger passe fro manner harbouring wherein like country host goodman house dooth chalenge lordlie authoritie ouer ghests cleane otherwise sith euerie man may vse inne owne house england haue monie great little varietie vittels seruice himselfe shall thinke expedient call innes also verie well furnished naperie bedding tapisterie especiallie naperie beside linnen vsed table commonlie washed dailie much belongeth vnto estate calling ghest ech commer sure lie cleane sheet wherein man hath béene lodged since came landresse water wherein last washed traueller haue horsse bed dooth cost nothing go foot sure paie penie whether horsseman footman chamber appointed may carie kaie owne house long lodgeth loose oughts whilest abideth inne host bound generall custome restore damage greater securitie anie trauellers gretest in england horsses like sort walked dressed looked vnto certeine hostelers hired seruants appointed charge goodman house hope extraordinarie reward deale verie diligentlie outward appéerance function calling herein neuerthelesse manie blame worthie doo onelie deceiue beast oftentimes allowance sundrie meanes except owner looke well also make pack slipper merchant hunt preie place sure euill wicked person manie honest man spoiled good trauelleth fro feat also counsell tapster drawer drinke chamberleins seldome behind wanting certes beleeue chapman traueller england robbed waie without knowledge commeth nine alighteth horsse hostler forthwith verie busie take downe budget capcase yard sadle bow peiseth slilie hand féele weight thereof misse pitch ghest hath taken vp chamber chamberleine looketh making bed sure remooue place owner hath set set conuenientlie else whereby getteth inkling whether monie short ware therof giueth warning od ghests hant house confederacie vtter vndoing manie honest yeoman iournieth waie tapster like sort part dooth marke behauiour plentie monie draweth paieth shot like end shall hard matter escape subtile practises thinke gay matter commit budget comming goodman house thereby oft bewraie themselues albeit monie safe time hand shall heare man robbed inne yet departure host make warrantise sith protection extendeth gate owne house cannot surer taken vnto prie watch booty sée anie ghest deliuer capcase maner innes haue plentie ale béere sundrie kind wine capacitie able lodge two hundred thrée hundred person horsses ease therto verie short warning make prouision diet vnacquainted withall may seeme incredible howbeit england worse in london yet manie far better best haue heard anie forren countrie circumstance dulie considered leaue go hand purpose set downe table best thorowfaires townes greatest trauell england twelue sixtéene innes least speake world sée ech owner contendeth goodnesse interteinement ghests finesse change linnen furniture bedding beautie roomes seruice table costlinesse plate strength drinke varietie wine well vsing horsses finallie much omitted among gorgeousnes verie signes doores wherein doo consume thirtie fortie pound méere vanitie mine opinion vaine néeds onelie giue outward token inne kéepers welth also procure good ghests frequenting house hope well vsed lo table hand innes shall néed speake waie walsingham london walsingham picknam 12 mile britaine called albion haue said name said albion established chiefe ruler king thereof grandfather osiris father neptune cunning sailour reigning therein bale saith space 44 yeares till finally slaine maner afore remembred vncle hercules libicus hercules thus vanquished destroied enimies hée passed fro thorough gallia suppressing tyrant euerie part came restoring people vnto reasonable kinde libertie vnder lawfull gouernours hercules find builded citie alexia burgongne nowe called alize moreouer lilius giraldus life hercules auouched hercules came ouer hither britaine dooth giraldus authoritie wrote vnto king countrie called pandrasus forme followeth letter brute pandrasus find set downe galfride monumetensis brute leader remnant troian people pandrasus king greekes sendeth greeting bicause hath beene thought thing vnworthie people descended noble linage dardanus otherwise dealt honour nobilitie dooth require haue withdrawne themselues within close couert wood haue chosen rather maner wild beast liue flesh herb dibertie furnished rich world continue vnder yoke seruile thraldome dooing offend thy mightie highnesse blamed rather behalfe pardoned sith euerie captiue prisoner desirous restored vnto former estate dignitie therefore pitieng case vouchsafe grant abridged libertie suffer remaine quiet within wood thay haue got possession yet giue licence depart forth countrie part sight letter request contemed made pandrasus first somewhat amazed howbeit deliberating matter considering small number made great account determined hand suppresse forcepandrasus prepareth armie suppresse troian ofspring grow greater multitudesparatinum bring intention better passe passed towne called sparatinum marching toward wood thoght haue found enimies suddenlie assalted brute thrée thousand men came foorth wood fiercelie setting vpon enimies made great slaughter vtterlie discomfited sought flight saue themselues passing riuer néere hand called akalon brute men following fast vpon aduersaries caused plunge water aduentureperaduenture achelous manie drowned howbeit antigonus brother prandrasus could stay grecian fléeingantigonus brother pandrasus calling backe againe get togither placed order began new field nothing auailedhe taken prisoner troians preasing vpon tooke prisoner slue scattred companie ceased till rid field aduersaries doone brute entering townebrute entreth sparatinum furnished six hundred able souldiours afterwards went backe residue people incamped wood receiued unspeakeable ioy prosperous atchieued enterprise although euill successe first beginning sore troubled pandrasus well losse field taking brother yet rather kindled desire séeke reuenge otherwise discouraged therefore assembling people againe togither scattered came next day towne sparatinum thought haue found brute inclosed togither prisoner therfore shewed whole endeuour hard siege fierce assault force within yeeld conclude long continued siege till victual began waxe scant within way yeeld present succour came remoue siege wherevpon signified necessitie vnto brute power sufficient fight enimies open field ment giue camifado aeuum qua tibi virgineis templa dicabo choris verse ponticus virumnius others also doo gesse written gildas cambrius booke intituled cambreidos may thus englished thou goddesse doost rule wood forrests greene chasest foming boares flee thine awfull sight thou maist passe aloft airie sky sheene walke eke vnder earth place void light discouer earthlie state direct course aright shew shall dwell according thy seates sure abode temple may dight virgin shall sound thy land voice shrill praier coremonie done according pagane rite custome brute abiding answer fell asléepe sléepe appeared said goddesse vttering answer verse following expressed brute sub occasum solis trans gallica regna insula oceano est vndi que clausa mari insula oceano est habitata gigantibus olim nunc deserta quidem gentibus apta tuis hanc pete nám que tibi sedes erit illa perennis hîc fiet natis altera troia tuis hîc de prole tua reges nascentur ipsis totius terrae subditus orbis erit brute farre bywest anew vnto thy race shall king borne dout mightie power world shall whole subdew awaked sléepe called dreame remembrance first doubted whether verie dreame true vision goddes hauing spoken liuelie countrie reached souht sea vnto riuer humber locrinus gouerned logiers brother albanact ruled albaniagal mon mat west fa g de co fine slaine battell king hunnes scythian called humber inuaded part britaine got possession thereof till locrinus brother cambergal mon mar west reuenge brother death recouerie kingdome gathered power togither comming said king hunnes valiancie people discomfited battellit seeme come ouer humber chased egerlie himselfe great number men drowned gulfe parted loegria albania tooke name said king called humber continueth vnto daie moreouer battell hunnes thrée yong damsel taken excellent beautiegal mon specially one whose name estrild daughter certeine king scythia estrild king locrine fell farre loue notwithstanding former contract made betwixt ladie guendoloena daughter corineus duke cornwall meant yet spéed marie estrild earnestlie called vpon manner forced thereto corineus hée changed purpose married guendoloena keeping neuertheles aforesaid estrild paramour still secret sort life corineus father law corineus departed world locrine forsooke guendoloena maried estrild guendoloena therefore cast hir husband got hir cornewall hir friend kinred procured make warre said locrine hir husband warres hée slaine battell fought néere riuer sture reigned writer affirme twentie yeares buried father citie troinouantmat west leauing behind yoong sonne begotten wife guendoloena named madan yet vnméete gouerne guendoloena guendoline wife locrinusshée numbred amongst reigned ruler land mat west daughter corineus duke cornewall much hir sonne madan yeeres sufficient gouerne common consent briton made ruler ile yéere world 2894 hauing administration hir hand right discreetlie vse hir selfe therein comfort hir subiects till hir sonne madan came lawfull age gaue ouer rule dominion gouerned space fifteene yearesgal mon madan sonne locrine guendoline entred gouernement britaine 2909madan third ruler world little left writing doings sauing vsed great tyrannie amongst briton therefore ruled land tearme 40 yeares deuoured wild beastes abroad hunting left behind two sonnes mempricius manlius builded reported madancaistre dancastre reteineth still later part name mempricius eldest sonne madan began reigne ouer briton yeare world 2949mempricius fourth ruler continued long peace brother manlius vpon ambitious mind prouoked briton rebell sore deadly warre continued long betweene finallie vnder colour treatie fabian manlius slaine gal mon manlius slaine brother mempricius liued tranquillitie rest howbeit deliuered thus trouble warres fell slouthslouth engendred lecherie vnlawfull lust lecherie thereby hatred people forcing wine daughter finallie became beastlie forsooke lawfull wife concubine fell abhominable sinne sodomie treating fell againe trie matter dint sword romane ambassadours also shew prowesse roman contrarie law nation forbidding came ambassage anie treatie peace take either one part tooke weapon hand ioined themselues clusians wherewith galles much displeased incontinentlie one voice required haue siege raised clusium might go rome brennus thought good first send messenger thither require deliuerie insued couetous sort galles contented iust weight gold cast sword also balance weight lay thereby haue ouer weight wherevpon roman refused make paiment weight thus whilest altercation matter one importunnate haue willing grant time passed till meane season camillus came amongst powercamillius •• appointeth galles poimet commanding gold away affirming without consent dictator composition agréement might concluded meaner magistrate gaue signe galles prepare themselues battell whervnto lightlie agréed togither went battell begun galles looked earst gold battellthe galles ouerthrowne easilie ouercome stood brunt slaine rest flight constreined depart citie polybius writeth galles turned siege citie war chanced amongst owne people home therefore concluded peace roman leauing libertie returned home againe howsoeuer matter passed thus much haue stept purpose shew somwhat noble famous capteine brennus onelie history also giouan villani florentine dooth report britaine themselues héereafter shall plainlie appéere neither doth make mention townes british histoie affirmeth built king déed latine writer speake diuerse people inhabited diuers portion land brigantes trinobantes iceni silures like part said people certeinlie inhabit hard auouch certeine truth iohn leland thinketh héereof one time curiouslie searched old antiquity shall heare occasion serueth likewise opinion otherhector boetius fault hector boetius coueting haue valiant act atchiued britain ascribed countriemen scot draweth silures brigantes britain farre northward maketh inhabitant scotish country particular name soeuer yet scot knowne generall name would persuade v beléeue saieng entred britaine ireland 330 yéeres incarnation sauiour neuerthelesse generall soeuer name scot sure speciall mention made anie writer till 300 yeares birth sauiour yet roman ruled land much adoo people thereof make mention • iuerse people nothing famous boetius would make scotish men euen leaue scot antiquitie originall beginning must doo vnto v descent brute troians sith contrarie dooth plainelie appeare vnlesse shall leane vnto presumption come time actes atchiued remaineth certeine record therefore may boldlie procéed historiemore certeintie hence forth appeareth historie season cassibellane roiall gouernment héere britaine caius iulius cesariulius cesar appointed senat rome conquer gallia purpose created consull sent mightie army countrie brought galles vnto framecaesar de bello gall lib 4 determined assaie winning britainebritains vnknowne roman yet roman knew otherwise report chiefest cause mooued take hand enterprisecaesar de bello gal lib 4 vnderstand dailie came great succour ile galles enimies vnto romanscauses warre though season yéere make warre farre spent summer almost end yet thought would good purpose might passe ouer thithercesars purpose learne maner people inhabit discouer place hauens entry apperteining ile héerevpon calling togither merchant knew haue traffike thither trade ware diligentlie inquired state ile could throughlie satisfied anie thing coueted know therefore thinking good vnderstand thing view might apperteine vse warre purposed follow attempted sent one caius uolusenus gallie light pinesse surucie coast ilecaius uolusenus sent ouer britaine commanding diligent search made returne spéed againe selfe also drew downewards towards bullenois whence shortest cut lieth passe ouer britaine part gallia day hauen called itius portus take caliceiohn leland word importethpolydor harbourgh able receiue great number ship unto hauen got cesar ship could next border party speciallie prouided put readinesse last yeare warres uannes armorica called britaine france caused brought thither lie till heare furtheruannes britane meane time indeuour knowne merchant reported britaine able beare armour commanded appointed repaire sea side might readie defend countrie time great danger inuasion ¶cesar commentary agréeth historiographer writeth immediatlie vpon knowledge would inuade britaine came ambassadours diuers city ile offer themselues subiects roman deliuer hostage whome exhorted continue good mind sent home againe also one comius gouernor artoiscomius commanding repaire vnto manie city britaine might exhort submit themselues roman maketh mention cassibellane till second iournie made ile time said cassibelane chosen ye shall heare generall capteine britain haue whole administration warre defense countrie nameth king howbeit british historie conteined cesar required tribute cassibelanewhich likelie • behalfe appeared sequel answered learned yet liue seruage defend libertie countrie weapon hand néede well perceiue blinded couetousnesse aduenture séeke disquiet britain caius volusenus discouereth caesar obseruations ile britaine maketh haste conquere britain defend countrie caesar consultation changeth landing place roman put hard shift britain begin giue backe courage roman ensignebearer sharpe encounter betweene army eleuenth chapter caius uolusenus within fiue day departure cesaruolusenus returneth returned vnto gallie decalred séene touching view taken coast britan cesar hauing got togither manie saile thought sufficient transporting two legion souldierscesar two legion souldiers passeth ouer britan ordered businesse thought expedient gotten conuenient wind purpose embarke himselfe people departed calice night third watch three foure clocke midnight giuing order horssemen take ship place 8 mile aboue calice follow himthe britans readie defend countrie howbeit somewhat slacked time ten clocke next day hauing wind touched coast britaine might behold shore set couered men warre britain hearing cesar ment verie shortlie come assembled armour resist aduertised approch land prepared themselues withstand cesar perceiuing determined staie till ship come lay anchor till 11 clockecesar calleth councell called councell marshal chiefe capteines vnto whome declared learned uolusenus also would haue doone willing thing might ordered reason warre required perceiued place first cast anchor méete landing people sith heigth cliffes closed ech side narrow créeke thrust britain might annoy people bowes dartes could set foote land hauing wind tide disanchored thence drew alongst coast vnder downesthis • bout day space 7 8 mile finding shore flat plaine approched néere land determining come shore britain perceiuing cesars intent spéed caused horssemen charets wagon cesar calleth esseda day vsed fight march forth toward place whither saw cesar drew followed maine armie wherefore cesar thus preuented inforced yet land people though saw haue much doo britain redinesse resist great huge ship could come néere shore forced kéepe déepe romane soldier put verie hard shiftthe roman put 〈◊〉 wit leape forth ship pestered heauie armour weapon fight water enimies knowing flat shelues stood either vpon drie ground else little waie shallow place water otherwise encumbred either armour weapon might bestir themseues laid load vpon roman arrowes dart forced horsses thereto inured enter water easilie annoy distresse roman wanting experience kind fight well able helpe themselues keepe order vsed doo land wherfore fought nothing lustilie woont doo cesar perceiuing commanded gallies depart great ship row hard shore placed ouer open side britain might shot arrow dart sling remoue britain cause withdraw water side thing put execution according commandementthe britans astonied britain little astonied strange sight gallies driuen ore earst séene shrewdlie galled also artillerie roman discharged vpon began shrinke retire somewhat backeshe valiant courage ensigne bearer herewith one bare ensigne legion surnamed decima wherein eagle figured chiefe ensigne legion saw fellowes nothing eager make forward first beséeching god enterprise might turne weale profit honor legion spake lowd voice word fellowes leape forth euen woorthie souldiers saith betraie ensigne enimies surelie acquit selfe according duetie towards common wealth generall therewith leaping forth water marched ensigne streight vpon enimies roman douting lose ensigne haue turned great reproch leapt ship fast might followed standard ensued sore reencounter troubled roman could keepe order neither find anie sure footing yet follow euerie man owne ensigne put themselues vnder ensigne first met withall first comming forth ship britain inured shelues shallow place water saw roman thus disorderlie come ship ran vpon horsses fiercelie assailed themthe fiercenesse britain great multitude britain would compasse inclose one companie also open place shore bestowed great plentie dart vpon whole number roman troubled verie sore roman get land english coast britain send caesar treatie peace staie romane ambassadour prisoner caesar demandeth hostage britain romane nauie driuen diuers way great tempest british prince steale caesar campe gather fresh power roman two army haue sharpe encounter twelfe chapter caesar perceiuing maner fight caused men warre enter boates small vessel commanded go place néed appeared relieuing fought new suppliesthe roman get land length roman got land assembling togither assailed britain fresh last put flightthe want horssemen roman could follow britain farre wanted horssemen yet behind slacking time could come land one thing séemed onelie disappoint luckie fortune accustomed follow cesar enterprise britain flight sooner got togitherthe britans send cesar speed sent ambassadours vnto cesar treat peace offering deliuer hostage stand vnto order cesar take anie reasonable sort ambassadours came also comiuscomius arras whome cesar haue heard sent britaine whome notwithstanding ambassadour sent cesar commission instruction sufficientlie furnished yet staied prisoner battell ended set libertie sent backe ambassadours excused matter laieng blame people countrie imprisoned lacke vnderstanding apperteined law armes nation behalfe cesar found great fault misdemenor onelie imprisoning ambassador also contrarie promise made sent gallia deliuer hostage lieu thereof receiued warre yet end said would pardon séeke anie reuenge folly herewith required hostagescesar demandeth hostage part deliuered hand made promise residue likewise sent crauing respit performance bicause fetched farre within countrie peace thus established fourth day roman arriuall britaine 18 ship ye haue heard appointed conuey horssemen ouer loosed hauen soft wind approched néere shore britaine roman cesars campe might see suddenlie arose great tempest none able kéepe course onelie driuen sunder caried againe gallia westward also ship lay anchor brought ouer armie pitifullie beaten tossed shaken great number onelie lose tackle also caried force wind high sea rest likewise filled water danger sinking perish quite lost moone night full therefore caused spring tide furthered force tempest greater periall ship gallies lay anchor way roman helpe matter wherefore great number ship bruised rent weatherbeaten without new reparation would serue vse sailing great discomfort roman brought ouer prouision liue winter season saw anie hope repasse againe gallia meane time british prince romane armie perceiuing greatlie mishap discouraged roman small circuit campe gessing could great number lacke vittels sore oppressed stale priuilie away one another campe purposing assemble power againe forestall roman vittels driue matter till winter might doo vanquishing closing returning trusted none roman thencefoorth would attempt eftsoones come britaine cesar mistrusting dealing staid deliuer residue hostage commanded vittels brought party adioining hauing stuffe repaire ship caused 12 vtterlie past recouerie hurt receiued violence tempest broken wherewith recouerie perceiued might repaired amended maner britain fighting charets roman giue fresh sallie britain put flight sue caesar peace king power assistant cassibellane battell caesar maner people encounter report diuers chronologers xiij chapter whilest thing dooing chanced one romane legion named seuenth sent fetch corne countrie adioining custome warre time suspected looked part people remained abroad field part repaired campe warded campe informed cesar appeared dust greater accustomed quarter legion gone fetch corne cesar iudging therof matter might meane commanded band warded go way foorth appointed two band come roomes residue people get armor follow quicklie gone anie great way campe might sée people ouermatched enimies much doo beare brunt legion thronged together britain pelted fore arrowes dart ech side sithens forrage left anie part countrie onelie place britain iudged roman would come thither therefore hauing lodged themselues within wood ambush night morrowe saw roman dispersed busie cut downe corne set vpon sudden sleaing brought residue order compassing horssemen charets great distresse maner fight charets beginning battell would ride side skirt enimies host bestow dart sate charets oftentimes braieng horsses craking noise charet whéeles disordered enimies woond themselues amongst troop horssemen would leape charets fight foot meane time guided charets would withdraw selues battell placing themselues people ouermatched multitude enimies might easilie withdraw charets mount vpon againe meanes wherof readie remooue horssemen stedfast stand battell footman supplie duty one charetmen exercise custome cunning feat although horsses put run gallop yet could stay hold backe pleasure turne wind fro moment notwithstanding place verie stéepe dangerous againe would run vp downe verie nimblie vpon cop stand vpon beame conuey themselues quicklie againe charet cesar thus finding people great distresse readie destroied came good time deliuered danger britain vpon approch new succor gaue ouer assaile enimies roman deliuered feare wherein stood comming furthermore cesar considering time serued assaile enimies kept ground shortlie brought backe legion campe thing thus dooing roman occupied rest abroad field got away followed sore season raine fowle weather kept roman campe staid britain offering battell meane time sent messenger abroad part countrie giue knowledge small number roman hope great spoile gotten occasion deliuer themselues danger euer might expell roman campe herevpon great multitude horssemen footman britain spéedilie got togither approched romane campe cesar although saw would come passe chanced enimies put repulse would easilie escape danger swiftnesse foot yet hauing thirtie horssemen comius arras brought ouer sent cesar ambassador vnto britain placed legion order battell campe comming ioine britain able susteine violent impression armed men fled roman pursued farre able ouertake anie slaieng manie burning vp house came backe againe campe immediatlie wherevpon euen day sent ambassador cesar sue peace gladlie accepting offer commanded send ouer gallia returned thither hostage number duble agréed vpon first thing thus ordered cesar moneth september wellneare halfe spent winter hasted season méet weake bruised ship brooke sea determined staie anie longer hauing wind weather purpose got himselfe aboord people returned gallia ¶thus writeth cesar touching first iournie made britainecaesar de bello gallieo lib 4 british historie polydor calleth new historie declareth cesar pitcht field vanquished firt encounter withdrew backe france beda also writeth cesar comming countrie gallia people called morini inhabited day inhabit diocesse terwine whence lieth shortest passage ouer britaine called england got togither 80 saile great ship row gallies wherewith passed ouer britaine first wearied sharpe sore fight taken grieuous tempest lost greater part nauie small number souldiers almost horssemen therwith returned gallia placed souldiors stéeds soiourne winter season thus saith bede british historie moreouer maketh mention thrée vnderkings aided cassibellane first battell fought cesar cridiorus alias ederus king albania called scotland guitethus king uenedocia northwales britaell king demetia day called southwales historie also maketh mention one belinus generall cassibellanes armie likewise nenius brother cassibellane fight happened get cesars swoord fastened shield blow cesar stroke androgeus also tenancius battell aid iof cassibellane nenius died within 15 day battell hurt receiued cesars hand although hurt slue labienus one romane tribune may well true sith cesar either maketh best thing owne honour else coueting write commentary maketh account declare néedeles circumstance anie matter chiefe point dealing againehector boet scotish historiographer write first knowne britain cesar would inuade came cassibellane king britaine ambassador vnto ederus king scot name king cassibellane required aid common enimies romains request granted 10 thousand scot sent aid cassibellane comming london ioifullie receiued cassibellane time knowledge roman come land beaten britain backe appointed resist landing wherevpon cassibellane whole puissance mightilie augmented onlie succour scot also picts common cause sent also people aid britain set forward towards place vnderstood enimies first approch togither cassibellane sent foorth horssemen charets called esseda thought disorder araie enimies twice incountred togither doubtfull victorie length ioined puissance puissance fought verie sore cruell battell till finally sudden comming welshman cornishman huge noise raised sound bel hanging trapper charets roman astonied therewith easilie put flight britain scot picts following chase without order araie reason roman kept themselues close togither britain scot picts scarse much harme enimies themselues receiued yet followed still vpon roman till darke night cesar perceiued withdrawne could assemble company togither minding next morning séeke reuenge former day disaduantage forsomuch knowledge giuen ship reason sore tempest beaten rent manie past seruice doubted least newes would incourage enimies bring people despaire wherfore determined fight till time conuenient sending wounded folk vnto ship commanded newlie rigged trimmed kéeping armie time within place incamped without issuing foorth shortlie drew sea side ship laie anchor within strong place fortified purpose lodged host finallie without hope atchieue anie exploit auaileable time tooke sea ship apt sailing repassed gallia leauing behind spoile baggage want vessel leisure conueie ouer ¶thus haue scot chronicle framed matter conformitie romane history according report british english writer therefore haue thought good shew héere diuersitie writer affection may better appéere sudden departing also rather fléeing iulius cesar britaine lucanus poet maketh mention reciting saieng pompeius oration made vnto souldiers wherin reprochfullie disdainfullie reprooued dooings cesar britaine saieng territa quaesitis ostendit terga britannis caesar taketh new occasion make warre britain arriueth coast without resistance number ship army incounter caesar forbad roman pursue discomfited britain repaireth nauie britain choose cassibellane cheefe gouernour skirmish afresh enimies haue repulse end xiiij chapter returne sequele matter cesar himselfe reporteth comming gallia two city britaine sent ouer hostage according couenant gaue occasion cesar picke new quarrel againstdion cassius wanted would yet doubt haue found full meaning make full conquest ile therefore purposing passe againe thither great desire bring britain vnder obedience romane estate caused great number ship prouided winter season put readinesse next spring found readie rigged six hundred ship beside 28 gallies héerevpon hauing taken order gouernance gallia absence caesar de bell gal lib 5 beginning spring came hauen calice whither according order prescribed ship come except 40 tempest driuen backe could yet come staied calice well conuenient wind incident certeine day length weather changed serued purpose tooke sea hauing fiue legion souldiers two thousand horssemen departed calice hauen sun setting soft southwest wind directing course forward midnight wind fell calme carried alongst tide morning day appéered might behold britaine vpon left hand following streame course tide changed forced • are fetch shore vpon part coast discouered tried last yeere best landing place armie diligence souldiers shewed héere great continuall toile droue foorth heauie ship kéepe course gallies length landed britaine noone next day finding one resist comming ashore learned certeine prisoner taken comming land britain assembled purpose haue resisted feare striken hart discouering huge number ship forsooke shore got vnto mountaines deed vessel one vittellers priuat men prouided furnished foorth owne vse ioined ordinarie number least eight hundred saile appeering sight one time made wonderfull muster right terrible eies britain procéed cesar got land incamped armie place conuenient learning prisoner part enimies withdrawne appointed one quintus atrius remaine vpon safegard nauie ten company cohort footman three hundred horssemen anon midnight marched foorth himselfe residue people toward britain hauing made 12 mile way got sight enimies host sending downe horssemen charets vnto riuer side skirmished roman meaning beate backe higher ground assailed romane horssemen repelled tooke wood refuge wherein got place verie strong nature helpe hand thought béene fortified time ciuill warre amongst entry closed trées béene cut downe purpose howbeit souldiers 7 legion casting trench found meanes put backe britain defense entring vpon droue wood cesar would suffer roman follow britain bicause nature countrie knowne vnto againe day farre spent would haue residue thereof bestowed fortifieng campe next day sent foorth haue pursued britain word came quintus atrius nauie rigour sore hideous tempest gréeuouslie molested throwne vpon shore cabels tackle broken destroied force vnmercifull rage wind maisters mariner able helpe matter cesar calling backe sent foorth returned ship finding state heard tooke order repairing vtterlie destroied caused drawne vp land trench might compasse plot ground might serue defense ship also incamping men warre leaue attend vpon safegard bicause least fortie ship lost violence tempest hope recouerie saw yet rest great labour cost might repaired wherefore chose wright among legion sent gallia wrote ouer left charge gouernment countrie prouide manie ship could send ouer vnto spent ten day repairing nauie fortifieng campe defense thereof done left within appointed returned towards enimies comming backe place incamped found readie resist hauing number hugelie increased britain hearing returned mightie number ship assembled part land general consent appointed whole rule order thing touching warre vnto cassiuellane cassibelane whose dominion diuided city situat néere sea coastcassibellane séeme ruled party oxfordshire barkshire buckinghamshire bedfordshire riuer thames 80 mile distant sea coast cassibellane time bin continuall warre ruler city land britain moued comming roman chose chiefe gouernour armie permitting order rule thing touching defense countrie roman onelie horssemen charets skirmished waie roman put backe oftentimes wood hill adioining yet britain slue diuers roman followed anie thing egerlie pursute also within roman busie fortifieng campe britain suddenlie issued wood fierselie assailed warded campe vnto whose aid cesar sent two chiefest cohort two legion placed little distance one another roman began discouraged kind fight britain therewith burst enimies came backe thence safetie daie quintus laberius durus tribune slaine length cesar sending sundrie cohort succour people fight shrewdlie handled appéered britain end put backe neuerthelesse repulse pleasure fortune quited themselues afterwards like men defending territory munition vntill time either policie inequalitie power vanquished shall sée course historie howbeit fine ouerrun vtterlie subdued without much bloudshed slaughter roman heauie armor great hinderance maner britain fighting warre incounter enimies discomfiture worthie stratagem martiall exploit cassibellane troinouants submission caesar sute touching mandubratius manie britain taken slaine roman xv chapter maner skirmishing fight chanced campe euen sight view men perceiued romansthe roman heauie armour reason heauie armour able either follow britain retired bold depart ensignes except would runne danger casting themselues awaie nothing méete match kind enimies horssemen fought likewise great hazard bicause britain would oftentimes purpose retire trained romane horssemen litle legion footman would leape charrets incounter foot battell horssemen dangerous like point whether pursued retired also maner britainsthe manner britain warres fought close togither sunder diuided company one separated another good distance troopes standing place conuenient might retire reléeue one another sending new fresh men supplie roomes hurt wearie next day thus fought campe roman shewed themselues aloft hill began skirmish romane horssemen hotlie doone day noone cesar sent foorth thrée legion footemen horssemen vnder leading lieutenant caius trebonius fetch forragecaius trebonius suddenlie brake euerie side set vpon forragers roman far foorth might breaking arraie going ensignes guidons gaue charge fiercelie repelled horssemen hauing legion footemen back dion cassius saith britain vanquished roman footman time put worst horssemen followed britain long might haue said legion sight readie succour need reason whereof slue great number britain giuing leasure recouer themselues staie might haue time get charrets chase discomfiture come party aid fellowes departed home day britain aduentured fight cesar maine power withdrawing beyond riuer ofwhich supposed kingston far thence thames determined stop enimies passing anie meanes might whereas one foord might come ouer cassibellane caused set full sharpe stake onlie middest water also comming foorth side lodged armie good order readie defend passage cesar learning relation prisoner tooke britain intended doo marched foorth riuer side foord armie might passe foot though verie hardlie comming thither might perceiue britain readie side impeach passage banke comming foorth water pight full sharpe stake likewise chanell riuer set pile couered water thing yet staied cesar appointing horssemen passe commanded footemen follow souldiers entring water waded spéed violence nothing appéering aboue water head britain constreined giue place able susteine brunt romane horssemen legion footemen abandoning place betooke flight cassibellane minding trie matter anie battell sent awaie part people yet kept foure thousand charretmen wagoner still watched waie roman tooke coasting euer marched kept somewhat aside within couert wood combersome place quarter vnderstood roman word passe gathered men cattell wood thicke forrests leauing nothing value abroad champion countrie roman horssemen come abroad countrie séeke booty sent charrets vnto knowne way passage skirmish horssemen much disaduantage roman durst straie farre maine armie neither would cesar permit least might haue béene vtterlie distressed britain depart maine battels footemen kept pace reason whereof countrie indamaged fire spoile onlie 〈◊〉 armie marched meane timetroinouants inhabited troinouants take middlesex essex men whose citie best fensed party thought called london sent ambassadours vnto cesar offering submit themselues vnto obeie ordinance besought defend mandubratius iniuries k cassibellane mandubratius fled vnto cesar france cassibellane slaine father named imanuentiusimanuentius chiefe lord king troinouants ambassador troinouants requested cesar onelie receiue mandubratius protection also send vnto might take gouernment rule citie hand cesar commanded deliuer vnto 40 hostage graine armie therewith sent mandubratius vnto themsome take troinouants londoner troinouants accomplished commandements spéed sending appointed number hostage also graine armie thus defended preserued iniurie souldiers people called cenimagni segontiaci ancalites bibroci cassi submitted themselues vnto cesar vnderstood towne cassibellane far place incamped fensed wooddes marishes great number people cattell substance withdrawne britain day cesar writeth called towne hold fortified anie thicke combersome wood trench rampire vsed get themselues auoiding inuasion cesar legion souldiers therfore marched thither finding place verie strong nature helpe hand assaulted two partes britain defending strength length able longer endure impression roman fled contrarie side towne enimies within place great number cattell found manie britain taken roman followed chase manie also slaine cassibellane dooth send vnto foure king kent aid caesar host offereth submission caesar britain become tributary returneth gallia remnant armie differing report caesar commentary historiographer touching warlike affaire sore fray bloudshed manslaughter vpon light occasion caesar taketh oportunitie get conquest land diuision betweene cassibellane androgeus time britain subiection roman xvj chapter whilest thinges passed sort partsfoure king kent cassibellane sent messenger kent vnto foure king ruled side land day cingetorix caruilius taximagulus segonax commanding assembling togither whole puissance assaile campe roman sea side certeine band lay ye haue heard safegard nauie according appointment came suddenlie thither roman sailed forth vpon sharplie fought lost diuers men slaine taken amongst prisoner roman tooke cingetorix one cassibellane heard newes sore troubled loss thus chancing one necke namelie discouraged diuers city yeelded vnto roman sent ambassadours mean romius arras vnto cesar offering submit himselfe cesar meaning winter gallia therefore summer drew towards end willing dispatch britaine commanded hostage deliuered appointed tribute britain yéerelie send vnto roman also forbad commanded cassibellane anie wise trouble indamage madubratius londoner receiued hostage brought armie sea found ship well repaired decked good point therefore commanded downe sea great number prisoner diuers ship lost tempest appointed transport armie ouer gallia two conueies doone good successe middest september though ship returning residue armie first conueie driuen force weather great number could come land place appointed cesar constreined fraught could get greater burden departed coast britaine safelie landed remnant people gallia good spéed could haue desired thought good leaue anie people behind himdion cassius knowing doo danger cast awaie could well remaine winter season doubt rebellion gallia contented take vp returne thither sith doone sufficientlie time least coueting might haue come perill lose alreadie obteined thus according cesar himselfe autentike author haue written britaine made tributarie roman conduct cesar ¶but histores farre differ thisgal mon matt west affirming cesar comming second time britain valiancie martiall prowesse beaten repelled first speciallie meanes cassibellane pight thames great pile trées piked yron ship entred riuer perished lost comming land vanquished battell constrained flee gallia ship remained ioy second victorie saith galfrid cassibellane made great feast london sacrifice god feast fell variance betwixt two yoong gentleman one named hirilda nephew cassibellane euelie eweline aliance androgeus earle london fell discord wrestling multiplieng word came dealing blowes meanes whereof part taken ensued sore fraie diuerse wounded hurt amongst hirilda king nephew slaine hand eweline king sore displeased herewith meant punish eweline according order lawes summoned appeare due forme make answer murder eweline comfort androgeus disobeied summons departed court androgeus contempt king lawes king reuenged vpon androgeus gathered power began make warre vpon androgeus perceiuing himselfe able withstand king puissance sent letter iulius cesar exhorting returne britaine declaring whole matter concerning variance betwixt king promising aid roman might iulius cesar ioifull message prepared nauie spéed mightie host imbarked came toward britaine yet would land doubting treason androgeus receiued hostage sonne named scena thirtie best noble personage dominion landed ioining androgeus came vallie néere canturburie incamped shortlie came cassibellane power britain gaue battell roman britain long fought knightlie borne themselues battell androgeus came people wing sharplie assailed britain constrained forsake field tooke themselues flight flight discomforted finallie fled gaue place roman pursued slue without mercie cassibellane residue people withdrew place suertie enuironed puissance roman androgeus seuen thousand men aid roman cassibellane end forced fall composition couenanting paie yearelie tribute thrée thousand poundsso saith campton galfrid monu saith fiue thousand cesar ordered businesse thought conuenient returned went androgeus fearing displeasure cassibellane reuerend father bede writing matter saith thus cesar returned gallia placed souldiors abroad countrie soiorne winter season caused ship made readie number 600 repassing britaine whilest marched foorth mightie armie enimies ship lay anchor taken sore tempest either beaten one another else cast vpon flat sand broken fortie vtterlie perished residue great difficultie repaired horssemen roman first encounter put woorsse labienus tribune slaine second conflict vanquished britain without great danger people marched riuer thames passable foord onelie one place else report goeth banke riuer cassibellane incamped huge multitude enimies pitcht set banke almost foord vnder water full sharpe stakesthe stake remained séene bede day token vnto day séene séemeth beholder euerie stake big man thigh sticking fast bottome riuer closed lead perceiued roman auoided britain able susteine violent impression roman legion hid themselues wood often issue gréeuouslie manie time assailed roman great damage meane time strong citie troinouant hir duke androgeus deliuering fortie hostage yéelded vnto cesar whose example manie city following allied themselues roman whose information cesar sore fight tooke length towne cassibellane situat betwixt two march fensed also couert wood hauing within great plentie thing cesar returned france bestowed armie place soiorne winter season scotish writer report britain roman first time repelled ye haue heard refused receiue aid scotish men second time vanquished scotish historie ye may sée length expressed thus much touching war iulius cesar made britain bringing vnder tribute roman tributarie subiection hardlie mainteined season ¶now noted cesar vanquish britain came amongst northerne men onlie discouering subduing part lieth towards french sea sith roman emperor earnestlie trauell bring britain vnder subiection euer redie rebell manie sundrie time cesar might séeme rather haue shewed britaine romanscornelius tacitus vit agr haue deliuered possession subiection brought ile maner one soeuer chanced yeare world 3913dion gassius building rome 698 birth sauior 53 first second yeare 181 olympiad comming brute 1060 conquest made william duke normandie 1120 1638 yeres present yere lord 1585 harisons account state britaine caesar offered conquer maner gouernement diuerse author report bookes contrarietie opinion obserued xvij chapter iulius cesar thus made britain tributary roman returned gallia cassibellane reigned 7 yeares vanquished ninth tenth yeare began first reigne reigned whole 15 haue 17 yeares diedfabian leauing issue behind hath bin old chronicle fabian recordeth saw followeth much booke wherein conteined cassibellane brother lud eldest sonne otherwise may thought saith cesar hauing vpper hand would haue displaced gouernement set vp androgeus right heire crowne sonne said lud whatsoeuer chronicle british history report matter appere cesar writeth partlie ye haue heard britaine day gouerned one sole princecaesar diuers diuers city estate themselues land diuided sundrie gouernements much forme maner germanie italie time city gouerned one onelie prince nobilitie people whereas diuers ruler day land called king large seigniory othercassibellane king cassibellane therefore called king though doo admit true yet may beginning brute entered land ordeined monarchie mentioned might continue posteritie manie yeares yet length comming cesar ciuill dissention might happilie broken diuided part remained onelie time cassibellane also long whilest liued tributary roman till finallie subdued saxon meane time discord negligence rather vnaduised rashnes writer hard iudge may affirmed receiued writing truth namelie concerning succession king said haue reigned betwixt day cassibellane comming saxon roman writer namelie tacitus report britain time past vnder rule kingscor tacit vit iu agr made tributary drawne prince sundrie faction defend kéepe common ieopardie scarselie would two thrée city agrée togther take weapon hand one accord fought part whole ouercome sort say britaine brought forme prouince roman gouernors vnder name legats procurator sent rule yet author make mention certeine king hereafter shall appeare romane emperor part earth subiection reigned britaine witnesseth gildas gildas epist saieng britaine hath king tyrant iudges hath wicked oftentimes spoiling tormenting innocent people cesar ye haue heard speaketh foure king ruled kent thereabouts cornelius tacitus maketh mention prasutagus cogidunussome take prasutagus aruiragus one man king britaine iuuenal speaketh aruiragus late writer lucius hereby appeareth whether one mo yet king britain bearing rule vnder romane emperor part common opinion chroniclewriters isgal mon chiefe gouernment remained euer britain romane senat receiuing yearelie tribute sent certeine time ex officio emperor lieutenant ile represse rebellious tumult therein begun beat backe inuasion enimies went inuade thus would writer inferre britain euer obeied king till length put beside gouernement saxon whereas common historie england succession king ought kept oft chanceth anie fill place one romane emperor placed stead another lieutenant said created king britain though emperor inferior vnto king britaine romane lieutenant appointment prescript senat emperours administred prouince may suffice aduertise contrarietie writer go foorth following historie haue doone heretofore sauing romane history write thing done emperor lieutenant shall shewed reason requireth sith great appearance truth oftentimes authorised allowed opinion learned theomantius tearme yeares reigned interred kymbeline within time whose gouernment christ iesus sauiour borne nation content obeie romane emperor consequentlie britaine customes britaines paie roman strabo reporteth xviij chapter death cassibellanetheomā tiu theomantius tenantius yoongest sonne lud made king writer doo varie best approoued affirme reigned 35 year died buried london leauing behind two sonnes guiderius aruiragus ¶but noted although history doo affirme well kymbeline also father theomantius liued quiet roman continuallie paied tribute britain couenanted iulius cesar pay yet find romane writer iulius cesars death augustus taken vpon rule empire britain refused paie tribute whereat cornelius tacitus reportethcor tacitus vita iu agr augustus otherwise occupied contented winke howbeit earnest calling vpon recouer right desirous sée vttermost british kingdome length wit tenth yeare death iulius cesar thirtéenth yeare said theomantius augustus made prouision passe armie ouer britaine come forward vpon iournie gallia celtica maie saiedion cassius hither part france receiuing aduertisements pannonians inhabited countrie called hungarie dalmatian whome call slauons rebelled thought best first subdue rebells neere home rather séeke new country leaue hazard whereof present possession turning power pannonians dalmatian left time warres britaine whereby land remained without feare anie inuasion made roman till yeare building citie rome 725 19 yeare king theomantius reigne augustus armie departed againe rome passe ouer britaine make warre comming gallia britain sent certeine ambassadours treat peace staied settle state thing among galles verie good order hauing finished went spaine iournie britaine put till next yeare 726 building rome fell birth sauiour 25 time augustus eftsoons meant third time haue made voiage britaine could agrée vpon couenants pannonians dalmatian aforetime staied himhe kept promise roman said meant haue gone britans euen salassians people inhabiting italie switserland cantabrians asturians rebellious sturrs raisedthose calice biskate withdrew purposed iournie whether controuersie appeareth fall forth betwixt britans augustus occasioned kymbeline prince britain haue auouch writer reported kymbeline brought vp rome knighted court augustus euer shewed himselfe friend roman chieflie loth breake youth britaine nation depriued benefit trained brought vp among roman whereby might learne behaue themselues like ciuill men atteine knowledge feat warre whether respect pleased almightie god dispose mind men present onlie britain manner nation contented obedient romane empire true britain euident enough strabos wordsstrab geog effect followeth present saith certeine prince britaine procuring ambassador dutifull demeanor amitie emperour augustus haue offered capitoll vnto god present gift haue ordeined whole ile manner appertinent proper familiar roman burdened sore custom paie ware either sent foorth gallia brought thence commonlie yuorie vessel shéeres ouches earerings conceit made amber glass like manner merchandize néed anie armie garrison men warre kéepe ile néedeth past one legion footman wing horssemen gather vp receiue tribute charge rated according quantitie tribute otherwise néedfull abate custom tribute also raised anie violence vsed dangerous least might prouoked rebellion thus farre strabo guiderius denied paie tribute roman preparation war side ridiculous voiage emperour caligula britain vanitie delight mischiefe aulus plautius romane senator accompanied souldiers arriue british coast without resistance britain take flight hide themselues xix chapter guiderius first sonne kymbeline harison saieth nothing began reigne seuententh yeere thincarnation christ guiderius man stout courageguiderius gaue occasion breach peace betwixt britain roman denieng paie tribute procuring people new insurrection one meane made open rebellion gyldas saithcaligula wherevpon emperour caligula thinke tooke occasion leauie power one vtterlie misliking negligence called augustus tiberius predecessor ment onlie reduce iland vnto former subiection also search vttermost bound thereof behoofe himselfe romane monarchie great prouision therefore made said caligula performe noble enterprise fourth yeere reigne like preparation made side guiderius resist forren enimies hauing thing readinesse ceassed dailie looke comming emperour whome ment receiue hard enterteinment durst aduenture set toward britainedion cassius lib 59 see sequele maine armie thus readinesse departed rome 79 yeere building citie marching foorth length came vnto belgike shore whence might looke ouer behold cliffes coast britaine caligula men stood gazing vpon great admiration woonder furthermore caused stand battell arraie vpon coast heard britain redinesse withstand entrance entring gallie nothing discouraged newes rowed flight shot two shore forthwith returned going vp high place like pulpit framed set vp nonce gaue token fight vnto souldiers sound trumpet therewith ech man charged gather cockle shell vpon shore called spoile ocean caused laid vp vntill time conuenientthe spoile ocean atchiuing exploit hauing none wherewith beautifie triumph séemed greatlie exalted thinking subdued whole ocean therefore highlie rewarded souldiers paine susteined collection cockle shell doone notable péece seruice also caried shell rome end might boast voyage brag well sped required therefore verie earnestlie haue triumph decreed vnto accomplishment enterprise saw senat grudge free liberall granting grace behalfe perceiued refused attribute diuine honor vnto recompense foolish enterprise wanted little slaine euerie one thence therefore went vp throne royall seate calling therewith common people told long tale aduentures chanced conquest ocean perceiued shout crie consented haue béene god great trauell valiant prowesse increase clamour caused great quantity gold siluer scattered amongst gathering whereof manie pressed death diuers also slaine inuenomed caltrop iron cast monie purpose doo mischiefe caltrop forme small sharp reason prease people much hurt doone yer perceiued end ridiculous voiage caligula attempted britain death caligulasuetonius emperour claudius suetonius saith moued warre britain sturre rebellion raised land fugitiues fled thence againe restored request made dion cassius writethdion cassius one bericus expelled britaine persuaded emperour claudius take warre hand time britain one aulus plautius senatour pretor appointed take armie soiourned france called gallia passe ouer britaine souldiers hearing voiage loth go men willing make warre another world therefore delaied time till length one narcissus sent claudius appease souldiers procure set forward narcissus went vp tribunall throne plautius declare cause comming souldiers taking great indignation therewith cried saturnalia haue celebrated feast daie called seruants apparelled maisters robe represented roome maisters serued béene seruants thus length constreined verie shame agréed follow plautius herevpon embarked diuided nauie thrée part end kept arriuing one place yet might take land another ship suffered impeachment passage contrarie wind droue backe againe yet marriners men warre taking good courage vnto rather séene fierie leame shoot east towards west way course lay made forward againe ship landed without finding anie resistance britain looked comming wherefore heard enimies land got wood marishes trusting lingering time roman would constreined depart chanced time past iulius cesar aforesaid end third booke fovrth booke historie england britain discomfited sore wounded slaine disabled plautius power claudius romane taketh chiefe citie cymbebeline king britaine bereaueth britain armour vertue conquest ouer part land surnamed britannicus first chapter plautius much adoo find britain lurking hole couerts howbeit traced first vanquished cataratacus togodumnus sonnes cynobellinus father dead verie long therefore fléeing waiesbodumni plautus receiued part people called bodumni subiects vnto called catuellani obeisance roman leauing garrison souldiorscatuellani passed till came riuer could well passed without bridge wherevpon britain tooke small regard defend passage though béene sure inough plautius appointed certeine number german vsed swim ouer riuers although neuer swift get ouer sleaing wounding britain horsses fastened wagon chariot britain able doo anie péece accustomed seruice herewithall flauius uespasianus afterwards emperour brother sabinus sent ouer riuer got side slue great number enimies residue britain fled next day proffered new battell fought stoutlie victorie depended long doubtfull balance till caius sidius geta almost point taken handle matter britain finallie put flight valiant dooings triumphant honor bestowed vpon although consull britain battell withdrew riuer thames néere place falleth sea knowing shallowes firme place thereof easilie passed ouer side roman following lacke knowledge nature place fell marish ground came lose manie men namelie german first passed ouer riuer follow britain partlie bridge lay within countrie ouer said riuer partlie swimming shift presentlie made britain hauing lost one rulerstogodumnus namelie togodumnus ye haue heard nothing discouraged rather egerlie set reuenge plautius perceiuing fiercenesse went staid placed garrison steed néed required kéepe place gotten spéed sent aduertisement vnto claudius according commandement anie vrgent necessitie mooue claudius therefore hauing thing hand readinesse straightwaies vpon receiuing aduertisement departed rome came water vnto ostia thence vnto massilia france sped iournies till came side ocean sea imbarking himselfe people passed ouer britaine came armie abode comming néere thames side ioined passed riuer againe fought britain pitcht field getting victorie tooke towne camelodunum count colchester chiefest citie apperteining vnto cynobelinus reduced also manie people subiection force surrender whereof called oftentimes name emperour ordinance roman lawfull anie take name vpon oftener anie one voiage moreouer claudius tooke britain armor weapon committed gouernment vnto plautius commanding endeuour himselfe subdue residue thus hauing brought vnder part britainedion cassius hauing made abode therin past sixtene day departed came backe againe rome victorie sixt month setting foorth thencesuetonius put flight great slaughter beda following authoritie suetonius writeth bréeflie matter saith claudius passing ouer ile neither iulius cesar neither anie stranger durst come within day receiued part countrie subiection without battell bloudshed gyldas also writing reuolting britain saith thus information thereof giuen senate hast made spéedie armie reuenge warlike nauie prepared sea fight valiantlie defense countrie square battell right wing anie prouision appointed shore séene backes britain stead shield shewed persecutor neck readie cut sword cold feare running bone stretched foorth hand bound like womanlie creature common prouerbe followed thereof wit britain neither valiant warre faithfull peace roman • leaing manie rebel reseruing bringing bondage land lie altogither vntilled brasse siluer gold stamped image emperour thus farre gildas british historie find report thus claudius comming aland porchestergal mon matth west besieged towne rescue whereof came guiderius giuing certeine foord passe ouer place supposed lie confines shropshire aloft vpon top high hill enuironed triple rampire ditch great depth hauing thrée entry directlie one aslope also saie compassed two riuers wit left hand riuer called clun right hand called teuid thrée side thereof clime verie steepe headlong waie easie come reach vnto onelie one caratac hauing thus fortified himselfe within place brought armie encourage people exhorted shew manhood affirming day armie wherein appeare beginning either libertie recouered else perpetuall bondage euer susteined rehersed also speciallie name elder resisted iulius cesar whose high valiancie liued free bloudie thraldome tribute roman enioied wiues child safe vndefiled thus discoursing manie thing hope assured victorie began raise cry ech one face fortification craggie higth hils set full enimies readie beat backe put great feare nothing saw afore séemed dreadfull assaile souldiers yet séemed verie desirous battell requesting bring protesting nothing able resist force noble prowes herewith capteins tribune discoursing like pricked forward earnest willes souliders fight ostorius perceiuing courage readie wils men warre well nothing like went afore whereas fearing punishment rebellion wailefull▪ countenance craued mercie neither countenance word shewd anie token discouraged mind pre • sented emperour claudius sitting tribunall seat vttered speach followeth béene much moderation time prosperitie nobilitie birth puissance come citie rather friend capteine neither haue thought scorne borne noble parent ruling ouer many people haue accepted peace waie ioining league present estate reprochfull honorable commandement horsses men armor great rich maruell loth forgo shall looke gouerne men must néeds follow men must slaues first yéelded selfe neither power glorie béene set foorth world vpon mine execution straight haue béene forgotten grant life shall witnesse euer mercifull clemencie emperour word pacified granted life caratake also wife brethen loosed band went also place empresse agrippina sat farre chaire estate reuerenced like praise thanks doone emperour senat called togither discoursed manie thing vanquished héerevpon determined ostorius enter citie rome triumph like conqueror prosperous successe hither followed afterwards procéedings luckie either caratake remooued waie bicause roman though warre beene finished looked negligentlie themselues either else britians taking compassion miserable state caratake worthie prince fortune froward aspect cast miserie earnestlie set reuenge quarrell héerevpon incompassed maister campe legionarie band souldiers left amongst silures fortifie place armie lodge succour come next town castels roman béene destroied siege head capteine yet eight centurion euerie one else company forward slaine shortlie set vpon romane forragers put flight also company horssemen appointed gard héerevpon ostorius set foorth certeine band light horssemen neither could staie flight meanes till finallie legion entred battell whose force staid length roman obteined better britain escaped flight without great losse reason daie spent manie bickering chanced occasion word emperor claudius vttered dissauour thus euen sicambres destroied remooued gallia likewise must silures dealt whole nation extinguished word blowne abroad knowne ouer caused silures conceiue woonderfull hatred roman fullie bent either reteine libertie die defense thereof vpon enimies swoord meane time ostorius scapula departed life right noble warrior one litle litle insuing step people rome haue subiects king vnder rule dominion shall note act déeds roman emperours c iulius cesar chased pompeie italie first obteined romane empire himselfe also prince emperours succéeding called cesars octauian tiberius caligula c maie easilie marke obserue people singular magnanimitie ambitious spirit gréedie honour renowne vnaptlie termed romani rerurn domini c didius sent supplie ostorius roome britaine trecherie lecherie queene cartimanda venutius keepeth kingdome spite roman meanes confines ile inlarged error hector boetius others touching siluers brigants nouants notified britain giue roman shamefull ouerthrow eight chapter deceasse ostorius scapulaa didius liuetenant one didius sent supplie roome yer could come thing brought order britain vanquished legion whereof manlius ualens conduct victorie set foorth britain vttermost bruit thereof might strike feare lieutenant hart vpon first comming ouer himselfe reported letter emperour largest manner end appeased matter might win praise put woorst preuaile excuse might séeme reasonable woorthie pardon siluers atchiued victorie kept fowle stur ouer country till comming didius driuen backe repelled héerewith began trouble raised another part caratac taken chiefest skillfull capteine britain haduenutius ruler iugants one uenutius ruler people named iugants man remained long time faithfull roman power defended enimiescartimanda married cartimanda queene brigants yorkeshire men cartimanda ye haue heard deliuered caratac roman hand thereby ministring matter emperour claudius triumph pleasure shewed roman increased thorough friendship power wealth whereof followed riotous lust satisfie hir wanton appetite falling square hir husband married uellocatus one esquiresuellocatus gaue hir kingdome dishonoured hir selfe héere vpon insued cruell warre much end uenutius became enimie also roman first tugged togither betwixt themselues quéene craftie policie found meanes catch brother coosens uenutius hir enimies nothing therewith discouraged kindled wrath hir ceassed go forward purpose manie brigants disdaining subiect vnto woman rule reiected hir husband reuolted vnto uenutius yet quéenes sensuall lust mixed wich crueltie mainteined adulterer uenutius therefore calling aid could get strengthened reuolting brigants brought cartimanda narrow point great danger fall hand hir enimies roman forséeing vpon suit made sent certeine band horssemen footman helpe hir diuerse incounters enimies firstuenutius keepeth kingdome despite roman doubtfull successe length preuailed deliuered quéene perill kingdome remained uenutius roman constreined still mainteine warre time legion also cesius nasicaled got vpper hand britain sent didius aged victory past inough renowmed inlarged thus haue ye heard successe britain mainteined warre defense libertie roman whilest claudius ruled empire according report romane writer ¶but must notethe error hector boetius hector boetius
